commit_message:
Functional tests for data migration middleware

Tests for the swift migration driver will ony run
with auth version 1.0 (the driver does not support
other auth versions).

Tests for the filesystem driver are limited because
the functional tests cannot set up filesystem source
directories or files.

Also adds data-migration to proxy-server pipeline in
proxy-server.conf.sample and enables swift migration
driver by default.

Change-Id: Ibaf213a853325d931289270c04de882487ccc3ab
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/73/123473/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/python # Copyright (c) 2014 OpenStack Foundation # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. import unittest from nose import SkipTest from uuid import uuid4 import test.functional as tf from test.functional import check_response, retry from swift.common.http import is_success class TestDataMigrationBase(unittest.TestCase): """ Base class for data migration functional tests. Can be extended to implement tests for specific migration driver(s). """ def _assert_header_in_response(self, resp, key, val=None, prefix=None): self.assertTrue(key in resp.headers, '%s not found in %s' % (key, resp.headers)) if val: self.assertEqual(val, resp.headers[key]) elif prefix: self.assertTrue(resp.headers[key].startswith(prefix), 'Expected %s header to start with %s but found %s' % (key, prefix, resp.headers[key])) def _assert_header_not_in_response(self, resp, key): self.assertTrue(key not in resp.headers, '%s found in %s' % (key, resp.headers)) def _skip_if_not_required_driver(self): # subclasses with driver specific tests should implement this method # to raise SkipTest if required driver is not present pass def setUp(self): if tf.skip: raise SkipTest # Determine whether this cluster has migration middleware if not, skip if tf.cluster_info: self.drivers = tf.cluster_info.get('data_migration', {}) if not self.drivers: raise SkipTest('Data migration middleware not configured') self._skip_if_not_required_driver() self.obj1 = uuid4().hex self.obj2 = uuid4().hex self.source = uuid4().hex self.dest = uuid4().hex def _do_safely(self, func, *args, **kwargs): try: func(*args, **kwargs) except Exception: pass def tearDown(self): if tf.skip: raise SkipTest if not self.drivers: raise SkipTest() self._skip_if_not_required_driver() self._do_safely(self._delete_object, self.dest, self.obj1) self._do_safely(self._delete_container, self.dest) self._do_safely(self._delete_object, self.source, self.obj1, use_account=2) self._do_safely(self._delete_object, self.source, self.obj2, use_account=2) self._do_safely(self._delete_container, self.source, use_account=2) def _put_container(self, name, headers, use_account=1): def put(url, token, parsed, conn): headers.update({'X-Auth-Token': token}) conn.request('PUT', parsed.path + '/' + name, '', headers) return check_response(conn) return retry(put, use_account=use_account) def _post_container(self, name, headers, use_account=1): def post(url, token, parsed, conn): headers.update({'X-Auth-Token': token}) conn.request('POST', parsed.path + '/' + name, '', headers) return check_response(conn) return retry(post, use_account=use_account) def _get_container(self, name, use_account=1): def get(url, token, parsed, conn): conn.request('GET', parsed.path + '/' + name, '', {'X-Auth-Token': token}) return check_response(conn) return retry(get, use_account=use_account) def _delete_container(self, name, use_account=1): def delete(url, token, parsed, conn): conn.request('DELETE', parsed.path + '/' + name, '', {'X-Auth-Token': token}) return check_response(conn) return retry(delete, use_account=use_account) def _get_object(self, container, obj, use_account=1): def get(url, token, parsed, conn): conn.request('GET', '%s/%s/%s' % (parsed.path, container, obj), '', {'X-Auth-Token': token}) return check_response(conn) return retry(get, use_account=use_account) def _put_object(self, container, obj, headers, use_account=1, body='blah'): def put(url, token, parsed, conn): headers.update({'X-Auth-Token': token}) conn.request('PUT', '%s/%s/%s' % (parsed.path, container, obj), body, headers) return check_response(conn) return retry(put, use_account=use_account) def _delete_object(self, container, obj, use_account=1): def delete(url, token, parsed, conn): conn.request('DELETE', '%s/%s/%s' % (parsed.path, container, obj), '', {'X-Auth-Token': token}) return check_response(conn) return retry(delete, use_account=use_account) class TestGenericDataMigration(TestDataMigrationBase): # tests for behavior common to any driver def test_bad_headers(self): def build_headers(provider, source, active): return {'X-Container-Migration-Provider': provider, 'X-Container-Migration-Active': active, 'X-Container-Migration-Source': source} bad = [((None, 'src', 'True'), 412), (('swift', None, 'True'), 412), (('bogus', 'src', 'True'), 400), ((None, 'src', 'False'), 412), (('swift', None, 'False'), 412), (('bogus', 'src', 'False'), 400)] for bad_values in bad: headers = build_headers(*bad_values[0]) expected = bad_values[1] resp = self._put_container(self.dest, headers) resp.read() self.assertEqual(expected, resp.status, 'Expected %s for headers %s but got %s' % (expected, headers, resp.status)) class TestSwiftDataMigration(TestDataMigrationBase): """ Test the swift migration driver by attempting migration between accounts in the test cluster. That is not its intended use case, but it will do nicely for functional testing. """ def _skip_if_not_required_driver(self): if self.drivers.get('swift') != 'enabled': raise SkipTest('Swift migration driver not enabled') def test_migration(self): if tf.skip2: raise SkipTest('Second account required') # set up migration from source in account 2 to destination in account 1 public_hdrs = {'X-Container-Migration-Provider': 'swift', 'X-Container-Migration-Source': self.source, 'X-Container-Migration-Active': 'True'} private_hdrs = {'X-Container-Migration-User': tf.swift_test_user[1], 'X-Container-Migration-Key': tf.swift_test_key[1], 'X-Container-Migration-Token-Url': tf.swift_test_auth} ignored_hdrs = {'X-Container-Migration-Ignored': 'ignore me'} headers = dict(public_hdrs.items() + private_hdrs.items() + ignored_hdrs.items()) resp = self._put_container(self.dest, headers) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) resp = self._get_container(self.dest) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) for key, val in public_hdrs.items(): self._assert_header_in_response(resp, key, val) for key, val in private_hdrs.items(): self._assert_header_not_in_response(resp, key) for key, val in ignored_hdrs.items(): self._assert_header_not_in_response(resp, key) # sanity check - source container doesn't exist yet resp = self._get_object(self.dest, self.obj1) resp.read() self.assertEqual(404, resp.status) self._assert_header_in_response(resp, 'X-Migration-Status', prefix='Object GET failed:') # create source container resp = self._put_container(self.source, {}, use_account=2) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # sanity check - object doesn't exist yet resp = self._get_object(self.dest, self.obj1) resp.read() self.assertEqual(404, resp.status) self._assert_header_in_response(resp, 'X-Migration-Status', prefix='Object GET failed:') # create source object source_obj_meta = {'X-Object-Meta-Test': 'test'} resp = self._put_object(self.source, self.obj1, source_obj_meta, use_account=2) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # object should now migrate resp = self._get_object(self.dest, self.obj1) body = resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) self._assert_header_not_in_response(resp, 'X-Migration-Status') self._assert_header_in_response(resp, 'X-Object-Meta-Test', 'test') self.assertEqual('blah', body) # object should remain in source resp = self._get_object(self.source, self.obj1, use_account=2) body = resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) self._assert_header_not_in_response(resp, 'X-Migration-Status') self.assertEqual('blah', body) # delete source object resp = self._delete_object(self.source, self.obj1, use_account=2) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # sanity check - object should no longer be in source resp = self._get_object(self.source, self.obj1, use_account=2) resp.read() self.assertEqual(404, resp.status) # object should still be in destination resp = self._get_object(self.dest, self.obj1) body = resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) self._assert_header_not_in_response(resp, 'X-Migration-Status') self._assert_header_in_response(resp, 'X-Object-Meta-Test', 'test') self.assertEqual('blah', body) # re-create source object resp = self._put_object(self.source, self.obj1, source_obj_meta, use_account=2, body='new content') resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # object should not migrate because it exists in destination resp = self._get_object(self.dest, self.obj1) body = resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) self._assert_header_not_in_response(resp, 'X-Migration-Status') self._assert_header_in_response(resp, 'X-Object-Meta-Test', 'test') self.assertEqual('blah', body) # delete destination object resp = self._delete_object(self.dest, self.obj1) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # object should not migrate because # destination delete time > source put time resp = self._get_object(self.dest, self.obj1) resp.read() self.assertEqual(404, resp.status) # re-create source object to create newer PUT time source_obj_meta = {'X-Object-Meta-Test': 'new test'} resp = self._put_object(self.source, self.obj1, source_obj_meta, use_account=2, body='even newer content') resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # object should now migrate resp = self._get_object(self.dest, self.obj1) body = resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) self._assert_header_not_in_response(resp, 'X-Migration-Status') self._assert_header_in_response(resp, 'X-Object-Meta-Test', 'new test') self.assertEqual('even newer content', body) def test_migration_teardown(self): public_hdrs = {'X-Container-Migration-Provider': None, 'X-Container-Migration-Source': None, 'X-Container-Migration-Active': None} private_hdrs = {'X-Container-Migration-User': None, 'X-Container-Migration-Key': None, 'X-Container-Migration-Token-Url': None} headers = dict(public_hdrs.items() + private_hdrs.items()) resp = self._put_container(self.dest, headers) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) resp = self._get_container(self.dest) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) for key, val in public_hdrs.items(): self._assert_header_not_in_response(resp, key) for key, val in private_hdrs.items(): self._assert_header_not_in_response(resp, key) def test_migration_loop_to_same_container(self): # set up migration to/from same container public_hdrs = {'X-Container-Migration-Provider': 'swift', 'X-Container-Migration-Source': self.dest, 'X-Container-Migration-Active': 'True'} private_hdrs = {'X-Container-Migration-User': tf.swift_test_user[0], 'X-Container-Migration-Key': tf.swift_test_key[0], 'X-Container-Migration-Token-Url': tf.swift_test_auth} headers = dict(public_hdrs.items() + private_hdrs.items()) resp = self._put_container(self.dest, headers) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) resp = self._get_container(self.dest) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) for key, val in public_hdrs.items(): self._assert_header_in_response(resp, key, val) for key, val in private_hdrs.items(): self._assert_header_not_in_response(resp, key) # attempt to migrate an object resp = self._get_object(self.dest, self.obj1) resp.read() self.assertTrue(400 <= resp.status <= 499) def test_migration_loop_to_different_container(self): if tf.skip2: raise SkipTest('Second account required') # set up migration from source to destination container public_hdrs = {'X-Container-Migration-Provider': 'swift', 'X-Container-Migration-Source': self.source, 'X-Container-Migration-Active': 'True'} private_hdrs = {'X-Container-Migration-User': tf.swift_test_user[1], 'X-Container-Migration-Key': tf.swift_test_key[1], 'X-Container-Migration-Token-Url': tf.swift_test_auth} headers = dict(public_hdrs.items() + private_hdrs.items()) resp = self._put_container(self.dest, headers) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) resp = self._get_container(self.dest) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # set up migration from destination to source container public_hdrs = {'X-Container-Migration-Provider': 'swift', 'X-Container-Migration-Source': self.dest, 'X-Container-Migration-Active': 'True'} private_hdrs = {'X-Container-Migration-User': tf.swift_test_user[0], 'X-Container-Migration-Key': tf.swift_test_key[0], 'X-Container-Migration-Token-Url': tf.swift_test_auth} headers = dict(public_hdrs.items() + private_hdrs.items()) resp = self._put_container(self.source, headers, use_account=2) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) resp = self._get_container(self.source, use_account=2) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # attempt to migrate an object from source to destination resp = self._get_object(self.dest, self.obj1) resp.read() self.assertTrue(400 <= resp.status <= 499) # attempt to migrate an object from destination to source resp = self._get_object(self.source, self.obj1, use_account=2) resp.read() self.assertTrue(400 <= resp.status <= 499) def test_migration_active_header(self): if tf.skip2: raise SkipTest('Second account required') # set up migration from source in account 2 to destination in account 1 # not yet active public_hdrs = {'X-Container-Migration-Provider': 'swift', 'X-Container-Migration-Source': self.source} private_hdrs = {'X-Container-Migration-User': tf.swift_test_user[1], 'X-Container-Migration-Key': tf.swift_test_key[1], 'X-Container-Migration-Token-Url': tf.swift_test_auth} headers = dict(public_hdrs.items() + private_hdrs.items()) resp = self._put_container(self.dest, headers) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # create source container resp = self._put_container(self.source, {}, use_account=2) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # create source object source_obj_meta = {'X-Object-Meta-Test': 'test'} resp = self._put_object(self.source, self.obj1, source_obj_meta, use_account=2) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # create second source object source_obj_meta = {'X-Object-Meta-Test': 'test2'} resp = self._put_object(self.source, self.obj2, source_obj_meta, body='second', use_account=2) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # object should not migrate - migration disabled resp = self._get_object(self.dest, self.obj1) resp.read() self._assert_header_not_in_response(resp, 'X-Migration-Status') self.assertEqual(404, resp.status) # enable migration on destination headers = {'X-Container-Migration-Active': 'True'} resp = self._post_container(self.dest, headers) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # object should now migrate resp = self._get_object(self.dest, self.obj1) body = resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) self._assert_header_not_in_response(resp, 'X-Migration-Status') self._assert_header_in_response(resp, 'X-Object-Meta-Test', 'test') self.assertEqual('blah', body) # disable migration on destination headers = {'X-Container-Migration-Active': 'False'} resp = self._post_container(self.dest, headers) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # second object should not migrate - migration disabled resp = self._get_object(self.dest, self.obj2) resp.read() self._assert_header_not_in_response(resp, 'X-Migration-Status') self.assertEqual(404, resp.status) # disable migration on destination with nonsense value headers = {'X-Container-Migration-Active': 'granola'} resp = self._post_container(self.dest, headers) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # second object should not migrate - migration disabled resp = self._get_object(self.dest, self.obj2) resp.read() self._assert_header_not_in_response(resp, 'X-Migration-Status') self.assertEqual(404, resp.status) # enable migration on destination headers = {'X-Container-Migration-Active': 'True'} resp = self._post_container(self.dest, headers) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # second object should now migrate resp = self._get_object(self.dest, self.obj2) body = resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) self._assert_header_not_in_response(resp, 'X-Migration-Status') self._assert_header_in_response(resp, 'X-Object-Meta-Test', 'test2') self.assertEqual('second', body) def _test_bad_parameter(self, key, bad_value): key = key.title() # set up migration from source in account 2 to destination in account 1 public_hdrs = {'X-Container-Migration-Provider': 'swift', 'X-Container-Migration-Source': self.source, 'X-Container-Migration-Active': 'True'} private_hdrs = {'X-Container-Migration-User': tf.swift_test_user[1], 'X-Container-Migration-Key': tf.swift_test_key[1], 'X-Container-Migration-Token-Url': tf.swift_test_auth} headers = dict(public_hdrs.items() + private_hdrs.items()) good_value = headers['X-Container-Migration-%s' % key] headers['X-Container-Migration-%s' % key] = bad_value resp = self._put_container(self.dest, headers) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # create source container resp = self._put_container(self.source, {}, use_account=2) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # create source object source_obj_meta = {'X-Object-Meta-Test': 'test'} resp = self._put_object(self.source, self.obj1, source_obj_meta, use_account=2) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # object should not migrate - bad source url resp = self._get_object(self.dest, self.obj1) print resp.read() print resp.headers self.assertEqual(404, resp.status) self._assert_header_in_response(resp, 'X-Migration-Status', prefix='Auth GET failed:') # try to update token-url alone part_headers = {'X-Container-Migration-%s' % key: good_value} resp = self._post_container(self.dest, part_headers) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # TODO - sending the token-url header alone does not update sysmeta # so this test will currently fail # # object should now migrate # resp = self._get_object(self.dest, self.obj1) # body = resp.read() # self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), # 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # self._assert_header_not_in_response(resp, 'X-Migration-Status') # self._assert_header_in_response(resp, 'X-Object-Meta-Test', 'test2') # self.assertEqual('blah', body) # send complete set of new headers headers['X-Container-Migration-%s' % key] = good_value resp = self._post_container(self.dest, headers) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) # object should now migrate resp = self._get_object(self.dest, self.obj1) body = resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) self._assert_header_not_in_response(resp, 'X-Migration-Status') self._assert_header_in_response(resp, 'X-Object-Meta-Test', 'test') self.assertEqual('blah', body) def test_bad_token_url(self): self._test_bad_parameter('token-url', tf.swift_test_auth + '_bad') def test_bad_user(self): self._test_bad_parameter('user', tf.swift_test_user[0] + '_bad') def test_bad_key(self): self._test_bad_parameter('key', tf.swift_test_key[0] + '_bad') def test_bad_headers(self): def build_headers(provider, source, active, user, key, url): return {'X-Container-Migration-Provider': provider, 'X-Container-Migration-Active': active, 'X-Container-Migration-Source': source, 'X-Container-Migration-User': user, 'X-Container-Migration-Key': key, 'X-Container-Migration-Token-Url': url} bad = [(('swift', None, 'True', 'user', 'key', 'http://i/v1/a'), 412), (('swift', 'src', 'True', None, 'key', 'http://i/v1/a'), 400), (('swift', 'src', 'True', 'user', None, 'http://i/v1/a'), 400), (('swift', 'src', 'True', 'user', 'key', None), 400)] for bad_values in bad: headers = build_headers(*bad_values[0]) expected = bad_values[1] resp = self._put_container(self.dest, headers) resp.read() self.assertEqual(expected, resp.status, 'Expected %s for headers %s but got %s' % (expected, headers, resp.status)) class TestFSystemDataMigration(TestDataMigrationBase): """ We can't do much functional testing of the filesystem driver since we have no access to the filesystem, but there are some sanity checks that are possible. """ def _skip_if_not_required_driver(self): if self.drivers.get('fsystem') != 'enabled': raise SkipTest('fsystem migration driver not enabled') def test_migration_setup(self): # we cannot test migration without knowing about the filesystem content # but we can at least test that a container is setup correctly public_hdrs = {'X-Container-Migration-Provider': 'fsystem', 'X-Container-Migration-Source': self.source, 'X-Container-Migration-Active': 'True'} ignored_hdrs = {'X-Container-Migration-Ignored': 'ignore me'} headers = dict(public_hdrs.items() + ignored_hdrs.items()) resp = self._put_container(self.dest, headers) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) resp = self._get_container(self.dest) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) for key, val in public_hdrs.items(): self._assert_header_in_response(resp, key, val) for key, val in ignored_hdrs.items(): self._assert_header_not_in_response(resp, key) def test_bad_source_path(self): # requests should fail if source path is bad public_hdrs = {'X-Container-Migration-Provider': 'fsystem', 'X-Container-Migration-Source': self.source + "/../bad", 'X-Container-Migration-Active': 'True'} ignored_hdrs = {'X-Container-Migration-Ignored': 'ignore me'} headers = dict(public_hdrs.items() + ignored_hdrs.items()) resp = self._put_container(self.dest, headers) resp.read() self.assertEqual(400, resp.status, 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) def test_good_and_bad_object_path(self): # requests should fail if object path is bad public_hdrs = {'X-Container-Migration-Provider': 'fsystem', 'X-Container-Migration-Source': self.source, 'X-Container-Migration-Active': 'True'} ignored_hdrs = {'X-Container-Migration-Ignored': 'ignore me'} headers = dict(public_hdrs.items() + ignored_hdrs.items()) resp = self._put_container(self.dest, headers) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) resp = self._get_container(self.dest) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) for key, val in public_hdrs.items(): self._assert_header_in_response(resp, key, val) for key, val in ignored_hdrs.items(): self._assert_header_not_in_response(resp, key) resp = self._get_object(self.dest, self.obj1) resp.read() # we cannot expect the file to exist, but the request should at # least cause an attempted migration self.assertNotEqual(400, resp.status) self._assert_header_in_response(resp, 'X-Migration-Status') # paranoia, but check for 404 before checking header value just in case # the file did actually exist on test system if resp.status == 404: self._assert_header_in_response(resp, 'X-Migration-Status', prefix='Failed to access object') resp = self._get_object(self.dest, '../../oops') resp.read() # migration should not be attempted with this file path self.assertEqual(404, resp.status) self._assert_header_in_response(resp, 'X-Migration-Status', prefix='File path is invalid') def test_migration_teardown(self): headers = {'X-Container-Migration-Provider': None, 'X-Container-Migration-Source': None, 'X-Container-Migration-Active': None} resp = self._put_container(self.dest, headers) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) resp = self._get_container(self.dest) resp.read() self.assertTrue(is_success(resp.status), 'Unexpected %s status' % resp.status) for key, val in headers.items(): self._assert_header_not_in_response(resp, key) def test_bad_container_PUT_headers(self): # check headers are validated when container is PUT def build_headers(provider, source, active): return {'X-Container-Migration-Provider': provider, 'X-Container-Migration-Active': active, 'X-Container-Migration-Source': source} bad = [(('fsystem', None, 'True'), 412), (('fsystem', '../../private', 'True'), 400)] for bad_values in bad: headers = build_headers(*bad_values[0]) expected = bad_values[1] resp = self._put_container(self.dest, headers) resp.read() self.assertEqual(expected, resp.status, 'Expected %s for headers %s but got %s' % (expected, headers, resp.status)) if __name__ == '__main__': unittest.main()

commit_message:
Add support for PowerVM Console

This change set adds support for the PowerVM VNC console.

Changes the remove vterm to always be invoked.  This shouldn't have a
performance impact if the console is not running.  Ensures proper clean
up on the system running the PowerVM API.

Change-Id: Ia6a5dd445410fcd5351c3528003a83ba659805bb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm refs/changes/28/180728/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: CONF.import_opt('vncserver_proxyclient_address', 'nova.vnc')

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-12 14:55:07.000000000', 'files': ['nailgun/nailgun/fixtures/openstack.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web/commit/3073aa9c08526c05df1df5dde7a68c87387b47a0', 'message': 'Moving Mellanox UI section to experimental mode

commit_message:
Moving Mellanox UI section to experimental mode

Since Fuel 6.1 Mellanox Features are implemented in a Fuel plugin.
Hence, Mellanox Features UI section is deprecated and moving to
experimental mode in Fuel 6.1 and will be deleted in Fuel 7.0.

Closes-Bug: #1452799

Change-Id: Ia0a0ebbd07e7ed5673b28ad5e200cb835e41d585

commit_message:
Set 'mtu=65000' for private network patchcord

While we create private bridge and connect it to corresponded linux
bridge we should define maximum MTU for transit patchcord.

Closes-Bug: #1453145

Change-Id: I78020ab270d0ac696e4d291b37e8985798ee4710
Signed-off-by: Igor Kalnitsky <igor@kalnitsky.org>

commit_message:
Drop use of 'oslo' namespace package

The Oslo libraries have moved all of their code out of the 'oslo'
namespace package into per-library packages. The namespace package was
retained during kilo for backwards compatibility, but will be removed by
the liberty-2 milestone. This change removes the use of the namespace
package, replacing it with the new package names.

Blueprint: remove-namespace-packages
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo-incubator/+spec/remove-namespace-packages

Change-Id: I783117608e1e6ea402e1c83309f80d994108baff

commit_message:
Fix setup script misspelling and pkill flag

pkill -9 docker was killing setup_docker.sh execution, so add -x flag.

Added check for root permissions and host type.
Added executing user to docker group.

Change-Id: I82cfad64fa737666d888e2ab9350c8d42e2150bf

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-12 02:41:55.000000000', 'files': ['nodepool/scripts/prepare_node.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/f4bb9920066ccb28260b85035bea986c3ba94794', 'message': "Don't disable cloud-init if not installed part 2

During scripted snapshot image builds we remove python-setuptools on

commit_message:
Don't disable cloud-init if not installed part 2

During scripted snapshot image builds we remove python-setuptools on
rhel/centos 6. This uninstalls cloud-init on hpcloud centos6 builds
because cloud-init depends on setuptools. We don't actually need
cloud-init in hpcloud because they use dhcp and we have hard coded ssh
keys so just don't bother setting cloud-init config if the config dir in
/etc does not exist.

One could argue that we would possibly want cloud-init to regen host
keys for us, but centos' sshd service should do that for us if the host
keys do not exist.

Change-Id: I96621b0ab1574eb8db0f4394877d3c1fc8208576

commit_message:
Don't disable cloud-init if it is not installed

When we're building nodepool images on top of minimal elements, there
will be no cloud-init, and therefore no need to disable cloud-init
datasources. In fact, trying to do so will be an error.

Change-Id: I98887c43566e07f2be9d2dc5fae6538078c7348e

commit_message:
Added more resources to ceilometer collector

Added support for network resources.
Added support for volume resources.
Improved image collector, now reports the size as the quantity.

Change-Id: Ifaffcc7b16585ddf0c1fce8a556eadef829af9b8

commit_message:
Don't require NODEPOOL_SCRIPTDIR to be set

If someone is building an image locally and don't want to do anything
special with nodepool scripts, they should not need to set an env var.
The env var obviously still needs to be honored for nodepool operation
and for override.

Change-Id: I08076a8eafe7019e715b1b46633e8f603031a1ea

commit_message:
Pass in keystone version and correct v2 URL to CLI

CLI tests for auth v2 were using the wrong URL, should be
CONF.identity.uri and not CONF.identity.auth_uri.  Also the
CLI requires the keystone version to be pass in (ie "3.0" for
keystone v3).

Change-Id: I7fd3994022bf4f4575cbffb75f48042d889792a9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-barbicanclient refs/changes/24/182024/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Check for code attribute in wrapped exceptions
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-08 18:47:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/solum/commit/aee44404f8fca056664760bcd5fecc00b02fc4b3', 'message': "LBYL when catching unmapped exceptions

When an unexpected exception is thrown in Solum,
the wrapping of those exceptions itself throws an error
because not every exception has the attribute 'code',
and the original exception is swallowed as the AttributeError
is surfaced.

By looking before assuming the exception has .code, we can properly
surface the exception at least as a 500 for further investigation.

Change-Id: I754d956e6c72f4ae94c3ec3573674aee4f7df0bc

the wrapping of those exceptions itself throws an error
because not every exception has the attribute 'code',
and the original exception is swallowed as the AttributeError
is surfaced.

By looking before assuming the exception has a code attribute,
we can properly surface the exception at least as a 500 for
further investigation.

Closes-Bug: 1453291
Change-Id: I754d956e6c72f4ae94c3ec3573674aee4f7df0bc

commit_message:
Check for code attribute in wrapped exceptions

When an unexpected exception is thrown in Solum,
the wrapping of those exceptions itself throws an error
because not every exception has the attribute 'code',
and the original exception is swallowed as the AttributeError
is surfaced.

By looking before assuming the exception has a code attribute,
we can properly surface the exception at least as a 500 for
further investigation.

Closes-Bug: 1453291
Change-Id: I754d956e6c72f4ae94c3ec3573674aee4f7df0bc

commit_message:
Drop use of 'oslo' namespace package

The Oslo libraries have moved all of their code out of the 'oslo'
namespace package into per-library packages. The namespace package was
retained during kilo for backwards compatibility, but will be removed by
the liberty-2 milestone. This change removes the use of the namespace
package, replacing it with the new package names.

The patches in the libraries will be put on hold until application
patches have landed, or L2, whichever comes first. At that point, new
versions of the libraries without namespace packages will be released as
a major version update.

Please merge this patch, or an equivalent, before L2 to avoid problems
with those library releases.

Blueprint: remove-namespace-packages
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo-incubator/+spec/remove-namespace-packages

Change-Id: I9891564317aa3cf84874debdc966e48fb270455e

commit_message:
Send the correct user-agent to Keystone

When we execute an Openstack CLI command, keystone should log in
Keystone access log that the user-agent that made the request was
'python-openstackclient' instead of the default 'python-keystoneclient'.
Therefore, when we create the authentication session we
need to send the explicit user-agent.

Closes-Bug: #1453995

Change-Id: I75087fd4bb1ff1e6f2a911bc70bf8008268276bb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/24/182124/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: USER_AGENT = 'python-openstackclient' user_agent=USER_AGENT,

commit_message:
Add keystone v3 API to fetch revocation list

Currently in auth_token middleware, only the v2 keystoneclient API is
used to fetch the revocation list. However, the v3 keystoneclient API
should be implemented and used as well. There should be a check on the
value of auth_version, and the corresponding API should be called.

Change-Id: I1c48da9afadfbdae2f69820e0b89bc02ec54000e
Closes-Bug: #1451445

commit_message:
Remove set controller RPC message

Instead of using the RPC message from the plugin
to the L2 Agent use the compute node configuration.
The local.conf Q_DF_CONTROLLER_IP parameter is used to determine
the sdn controller ip and port

Change-Id: I43f47ca62b14a8b46165df222d0c65a868bedf4c

commit_message:
Expose function to get defaults dict

shade needs sane defaults for some of these too, but it's entirely
legitimate to use shade without having first created an os_client_config
object. Adding a function to get a copy of the defaults dict allows it to be
consumed as a single source or truth for default values.

Change-Id: I616d9492c7e0f53c48519cc8dacf3dfbd0082e36

added_lines: # Copyright 2014 # The Cloudscaling Group, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. from ec2api.api import common from ec2api.api import ec2utils from ec2api.db import api as db_api from ec2api import exception from ec2api.i18n import _ Validator = common.Validator DEFAULT_BGP_ASN = 65000 def create_customer_gateway(context, ip_address, type, bgp_asn=None): if bgp_asn and bgp_asn != DEFAULT_BGP_ASN: raise exception.Unsupported("BGP dynamic routing is unsupported") cgw = next((cgw for cgw in db_api.get_items(context, 'cgw') if cgw['ip_address'] == ip_address), None) if not cgw: cgw = db_api.add_item(context, 'cgw', {'ip_address': ip_address}) return {'customerGateway': _format_customer_gateway(cgw)} def delete_customer_gateway(context, customer_gateway_id): cgw = ec2utils.get_db_item(context, customer_gateway_id) vpn_connections = db_api.get_items(context, 'vpn') if any(vpn['customer_gateway_id'] == cgw['id'] for vpn in vpn_connections): raise exception.IncorrectState( reason=_('The customer gateway is in use.')) db_api.delete_item(context, cgw['id']) return True def describe_customer_gateways(context, customer_gateway_id=None, filter=None): formatted_cgws = CustomerGatewayDescriber().describe( context, ids=customer_gateway_id, filter=filter) return {'customerGatewaySet': formatted_cgws} class CustomerGatewayDescriber(common.TaggableItemsDescriber, common.NonOpenstackItemsDescriber): KIND = 'cgw' FILTER_MAP = {'bgp-asn': 'bgpAsn', 'customer-gateway-id': 'customerGatewayId', 'ip-address': 'ipAddress', 'state': 'state', 'type': 'type'} def format(self, cgw): return _format_customer_gateway(cgw) def _format_customer_gateway(cgw): return {'customerGatewayId': cgw['id'], 'type': 'ipsec.1', 'state': 'available', 'bgpAsn': DEFAULT_BGP_ASN, 'ipAddress': cgw['ip_address']}

subject: Only add fall through cloud as a fall through
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-09 13:25:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/os-client-config/commit/a76378153b1aacf78eec2f822410668fc5529db6', 'message': "Only add fall through cloud as a fall through

We only want do define the 'openstack' cloud if there are neither
environment varaibles nor config files. We need to define it as a place
to put passed-in-parameters in the case of neither, but we don't want it
any other time.

The behavior can now be described as:
- If you have a config file, you will get the clouds listed in it
- If you have environment variable, you will get a cloud named 'envvars'
- If you have neither, you will get a cloud named 'openstack'

Change-Id: I6752c1ccecf1ef979b2603246eeaab7da360c8a4

environment varaibles nor config files. We need to define it as a place
to put passed-in-parameters in the case of neither, but we don't want it
any other time.

commit_message:
Only add fall through cloud as a fall through

We only want do define the 'openstack' cloud if there are neither
environment varaibles nor config files. We need to define it as a place
to put passed-in-parameters in the case of neither, but we don't want it
any other time.

The behavior can now be described as:
- If you have a config file, you will get the clouds listed in it
- If you have environment variable, you will get a cloud named 'envvars'
- If you have neither, you will get a cloud named 'defaults'

Change-Id: I6752c1ccecf1ef979b2603246eeaab7da360c8a4

commit_message:
Drop use of 'oslo' namespace package

The Oslo libraries have moved all of their code out of the 'oslo'
namespace package into per-library packages. The namespace package was
retained during kilo for backwards compatibility, but will be removed by
the liberty-2 milestone. This change removes the use of the namespace
package, replacing it with the new package names.

The patches in the libraries will be put on hold until application
patches have landed, or L2, whichever comes first. At that point, new
versions of the libraries without namespace packages will be released as
a major version update.

Please merge this patch, or an equivalent, before L2 to avoid problems
with those library releases.

Blueprint: remove-namespace-packages
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo-incubator/+spec/remove-namespace-packages

Change-Id: I474dcd9de166b00d02b3586858a28797e97a3231

commit_message:
Small changes in report_tempest_results.py

Earlier for test runs with the same names but different configurations
two test plan entries were created. Now for such test runs one test
plan entry is created.

Change-Id: I7f8fdea20fa32487d7dc9a4cef7df4eedbbc5172

commit_message:
Implement the find metric names resource for vertica

Change-Id: I7400b66a3927a8a5118509282ef7046ecde7083e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-api refs/changes/07/182307/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import monasca.api.domain.model.metric.MetricDefinitionRepo;import monasca.api.infrastructure.persistence.DimensionQueries; import org.apache.commons.codec.DecoderException; import org.apache.commons.codec.binary.Hex; import org.skife.jdbi.v2.DBI; import org.skife.jdbi.v2.Handle; import org.skife.jdbi.v2.Query; import org.slf4j.Logger; import org.slf4j.LoggerFactory; private static final String FIND_METRIC_DEFS_SQL = private static final String FIND_METRIC_NAMES_SQL = "select distinct def.id, def.name " + "from MonMetrics.Definitions def, MonMetrics.DefinitionDimensions defdims " + "left outer join MonMetrics.Dimensions dims on dims.dimension_set_id = defdims.dimension_set_id " + "%s " + "where def.id = defdims.definition_id and def.tenant_id = :tenantId " + "%s " + "order by def.id, def.name ASC " + "limit :limit"; public List<MetricName> findNames( String tenantId, Map<String, String> dimensions, String offset, int limit) throws Exception { List<Map<String, Object>> rows = executeMetricNameQuery(tenantId, dimensions, offset, limit); List<MetricName> metricNameList = new ArrayList<>(rows.size()); for (Map<String, Object> row : rows) { byte[] defId = (byte[]) row.get("id"); String name = (String) row.get("name"); MetricName metricName = new MetricName(Hex.encodeHexString(defId), name); metricNameList.add(metricName); } return metricNameList; } private List<Map<String, Object>> executeMetricNameQuery( String tenantId, Map<String, String> dimensions, String offset, int limit) { StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(); if (offset != null && !offset.isEmpty()) { sb.append(" and def.id > :offset"); } String sql = String.format(FIND_METRIC_NAMES_SQL, MetricQueries.buildJoinClauseFor(dimensions), sb); try (Handle h = db.open()) { Query<Map<String, Object>> query = h.createQuery(sql) .bind("tenantId", tenantId) .bind("limit", limit + 1); if (offset != null && !offset.isEmpty()) { logger.debug("binding offset: {}", offset); try { query.bind("offset", Hex.decodeHex(offset.toCharArray())); } catch (DecoderException e) { throw Exceptions.badRequest("failed to decode offset " + offset, e); } } DimensionQueries.bindDimensionsToQuery(query, dimensions); return query.list(); } } @Override List<Map<String, Object>> rows = executeMetricQuery(tenantId, name, dimensions, offset, limit); List<MetricDefinition> metricDefs = new ArrayList<>(rows.size()); byte[] currentDefDimId = null; Map<String, String> dims = null; for (Map<String, Object> row : rows) { byte[] defDimId = (byte[]) row.get("id"); String metricName = (String) row.get("name"); String dimName = (String) row.get("dname"); String dimValue = (String) row.get("dvalue"); if (defDimId == null || !Arrays.equals(currentDefDimId, defDimId)) { currentDefDimId = defDimId; dims = new HashMap<>(); if (dimName != null && dimValue != null) { dims.put(dimName, dimValue); } MetricDefinition m = new MetricDefinition(metricName, dims); m.setId(Hex.encodeHexString(defDimId)); metricDefs.add(m); } else { dims.put(dimName, dimValue); } } return metricDefs; } private List<Map<String, Object>> executeMetricQuery( String tenantId, String name, Map<String, String> dimensions, String offset, int limit) { String sql = String.format(FIND_METRIC_DEFS_SQL, MetricQueries.buildJoinClauseFor(dimensions), sb); return query.list(); } }

commit_message:
Check type match on create from source/snap

We used to allow creating from source/snap and specifying a
different type than the originating resource when doing so.

Once we started getting more drivers and more multi-backend
configurations, we implemented a check in volume.api that
took this away (broke it).  There have been a number of
arguments about whether this should be allowed or not, and
that it could fail after the rpc call leaving the user with
nothing more than a "failed" volume and no explanation as to
why.

This patch allows the capability, but checks validity at the
API layer before issuing the create call.  There are two
requirements for the new type specification to be valid:
1. There is only one backend (cinder-volume) topic configured
2. Both types in question specify the same volume_backend_name

If neither of these requirements are met, the user will receive
an "invalid type" error explaining that the type combination is
not compatible and that they should omit the type argument altogether.

Change-Id: I35f245bac47ff83ca4065691fd64d11b5feaa300
Closes-Bug: #1289931

commit_message:
Add field name to error messages in object type checking

The coerce() methods in object fields generate ValueError
exceptions if an incorrect type is used. Most of the messages
do not indicate which field was involved although that information
is available in the coerce() methods. This change adds the
field name to the error messages.

Ported from:
Ic94d52f6019c5a5a291675e321f96f5c65beaf10

Co-Authored-By: Paul Murray <pmurray@hp.com>
Closes-Bug:  #1430681

Change-Id: I4a359ea1478481e81f66c9c20e0bcac79ccd6a3a

commit_message:
Add enum fieldtype field

In some case, one field should be limited to some value, like the
cpu architect field.

Make sure that when the value limitation is changed,
the fingerprint will be changed, so that a version bump should happen.

Ported (but changed for consistency) from:
I7848f8b934c169a76b1cfd875f7905273f9f914b

Co-Authored-By: yunhong jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>
Co-Authored-By: Dan Smith <dansmith@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Iac498869d10d2238b3ddf704640cd152cb794099

added_lines: class Enum(String): def __init__(self, valid_values=None, **kwargs): self._valid_values = valid_values super(Enum, self).__init__(**kwargs) def coerce(self, obj, attr, value): if self._valid_values and value not in self._valid_values: msg = _("Field value %s is invalid") % value raise ValueError(msg) return super(Enum, self).coerce(obj, attr, value) def stringify(self, value): if self._valid_values and value not in self._valid_values: msg = _("Field value %s is invalid") % value raise ValueError(msg) return super(Enum, self).stringify(value) class EnumField(AutoTypedField): def __init__(self, valid_values=None, **kwargs): self.AUTO_TYPE = Enum(valid_values=valid_values) super(EnumField, self).__init__(**kwargs) def __repr__(self): valid_values = self._type._valid_values args = { 'nullable': self._nullable, 'default': self._default, } if valid_values: args.update({'valid_values': valid_values}) return '%s(%s)' % (self._type.__class__.__name__, ','.join(['%s=%s' % (k, v) for k, v in args.items()])) class ListOfEnumField(AutoTypedField): def __init__(self, valid_values=None, **kwargs): self.AUTO_TYPE = List(Enum(valid_values=valid_values)) super(ListOfEnumField, self).__init__(**kwargs) def __repr__(self): valid_values = self._type._element_type._type._valid_values args = { 'nullable': self._nullable, 'default': self._default, } if valid_values: args.update({'valid_values': valid_values}) return '%s(%s)' % (self._type.__class__.__name__, ','.join(['%s=%s' % (k, v) for k, v in args.items()]))

commit_message:
Adds missing WebOb in requirements.txt

Unit tests are failing without it, and the file
oslo_versionedobjects/exception.py has:
import webob.exc

So it's looking like webob is missing from requirements.txt.
This patch fixes that. Note that this should be fixed in
the kilo branch later on.

Change-Id: Ib0ac48aeea4f8413740af89340e3b094312fa6b4
(cherry picked from commit c7ff6a07cc1f5ff26823836debc66fa965912ff4)

commit_message:
Uncap pymongo

Workarounds have been implemented so that OpenStack now works with
both pymongo 3.0 and earlier versions, so this cap can be removed.

Change-Id: Iabb723cf4129b094b69276deaff1126da033ab18
Closes-Bug: 1441393

commit_message:
Add support to add Tuskar-ui config to local_settings

Patch adds optional configuration for Tuskar-UI to local_settings template
so it is possible to to use puppet-horizon for Tuskar-UI post install
configuration

Change-Id: Iaacd9e1a95a38093bc442375151f2e05dd13771f

ovs is the Python library for interacting with Open vSwitch.  Neutron
already uses this (starting in the Kilo release) but it was only just
now added to PyPI.

Info "For new Requirements" from the README:

- Is the library actively maintained?

Yes.  It's included in the main openvswitch git tree and is maintained
by the ovs team.

- Is the library good code?

Yes.

- Is the library python 3 compatible?

More testing is required as it's not clear what testing has already
been done.  It has no additional dependencies and I'm not aware of
anything else that would make Python 3 compatibility difficult.

- Is the library license compatible?

Yes.  Apache 2

- Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu
  latest / Fedora latest)?

Yes.  This is already an OpenStack dependency.  It was just only
recently uploaded to PyPI to make testing in our CI easier.

- Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries
  in ``global-requirements.txt``?

No.

Change-Id: Ieb40dce8448d8d10150540238e2ab8dded5bc743
'}]
commit_message:
global-requirements: Add ovs

ovs is the Python library for interacting with Open vSwitch.  Neutron
already uses this (starting in the Kilo release) but it was only just
now added to PyPI.

Info "For new Requirements" from the README:

- Is the library actively maintained?

Yes.  It's included in the main openvswitch git tree and is maintained
by the ovs team.

- Is the library good code?

Yes.

- Is the library python 3 compatible?

More testing is required as it's not clear what testing has already
been done.  It has no additional dependencies and I'm not aware of
anything else that would make Python 3 compatibility difficult.

- Is the library license compatible?

Yes.  Apache 2

- Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu
  latest / Fedora latest)?

Yes.  This is already an OpenStack dependency.  It was just only
recently uploaded to PyPI to make testing in our CI easier.

- Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries
  in ``global-requirements.txt``?

No.

Change-Id: Ieb40dce8448d8d10150540238e2ab8dded5bc743

commit_message:
Bump cryptography to 0.8.2 for thread safety fix

A critical update to python cryptography was included in version
0.8.2, just released.  This update included a single fix for a
thread safety issue when initializing the OpenSSL backend used
for Fernet.

See https://cryptography.io/en/latest/changelog/#id1

Change-Id: I8453190d2b886bef776e207c28b063ebd12db20a

commit_message:
Force specify false for service management params

If the stack is deployed in a pacemaker setup force specify false for
all related service management parameters.

Aternative solution: I98a466c719afcc8737d8224e9a64aa5dffe86065

Change-Id: I1de69504e9aa3b788854ffc81387701fc82b5bf6

commit_message:
Create ServiceManage,ServiceEnabled,ServiceEnsure

This commits create three new parameters:

  * ServiceManage
  * ServiceEnabled
  * ServiceEnsure

Those parameters based on whether it is a (non-)pacemaker deployment
will be set to true or false to let the installer know how to deal about
service management.

Alternative Solution: I1de69504e9aa3b788854ffc81387701fc82b5bf6

Change-Id: I98a466c719afcc8737d8224e9a64aa5dffe86065

subject: Check master node connection to repositories
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-07 12:30:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web/commit/e8f898b1336c2b20aa7d3935a36f9bfc84a5a62a', 'message': 'Check master node connection to repositories

Added CheckRepositoryConnectionTask which tries to retrieve files from

before provisioning takes place, so it covers the IBP need

commit_message:
Check master node connection to repositories

Added CheckRepositoryConnectionTask which tries to retrieve files from
repositories and fails if it cannot do it. This check is performed
before provisioning takes place, so it covers the IBP need
for master node to have access to repositories for building an image.

Above task is mocked for integration tests.

Fake task mode causes retrieving failed repositories method to be
replaced by method always returning empty list.

Change-Id: I1af89833e7de8447e73b9d9f00dcc2d9170ea35f
Partial-Bug: #1439686

commit_message:
Rewrite extension checking methods

Old implementation didn't work, was using ad-hoc caching and its name
was too generic. Moreover it exposed 2 methods that should be private
as Shade aims to hide implementation details.

This change-set gets rid of extension_cache() and has_extension()
methods and create _nova_extensions() and _has_nova_extension()
methods.
Caching is performed using _cache_on_arguments decorator.

Change-Id: I6aa3ed5a306159ba477d15810138b3a4fb5a3649
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/35/181935/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @_cache_on_arguments() def _nova_extensions(self): extensions = set() try: resp, body = self.manager.submitTask( _tasks.NovaUrlGet(url='/extensions')) for x in body['extensions']: extensions.add(x['alias']) except Exception as e: self.log.debug( "nova could not list extensions: {msg}".format( msg=str(e)), exc_info=True) raise OpenStackCloudException( "error fetching extension list for nova: {msg}".format( msg=str(e))) return extensions def _has_nova_extension(self, extension_name): return extension_name in self._nova_extensions()
deleted_lines: from novaclient import exceptions as nova_exceptions @property def extension_cache(self): if not self._extension_cache: self._extension_cache = set() try: resp, body = self.manager.submitTask( _tasks.NovaUrlGet(url='/extensions')) if resp.status_code == 200: for x in body['extensions']: self._extension_cache.add(x['alias']) except nova_exceptions.NotFound: pass return self._extension_cache def has_extension(self, extension_name): return extension_name in self.extension_cache

commit_message:
Update images API for get/list/search interface

Images API now conforms to the new search interface. This required
us to no longer return a dict of images keyed by image ID, but, rather,
just a list if images.

The 'exclude' argument to get_image() was not being used by either
nodepool or the Ansible modules, so this was simply removed to make
that method conform to the standard interface. However, it is still
used by the Ansible modules in get_image_id(), so that functionality
is kept intact.

Change-Id: Icf825fcb0471de4acb08b59b93a4dfcd399b4c69
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/00/180600/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: for image in images: def search_images(self, name_or_id=None, filters=None): images = self.list_images() return self._filter_list(images, name_or_id, filters) @_cache_on_arguments(should_cache_fn=_no_pending_images) def list_images(self, filter_deleted=True): """Get available glance images. :param filter_deleted: Control whether deleted images are returned. :returns: A list of glance images. """ # First, try to actually get images from glance, it's more efficient images = [] try: # If the cloud does not expose the glance API publically image_list = meta.obj_list_to_dict( self.manager.submitTask(_tasks.GlanceImageList()) ) except (OpenStackCloudException, glanceclient.exc.HTTPInternalServerError): # We didn't have glance, let's try nova # If this doesn't work - we just let the exception propagate image_list = meta.obj_list_to_dict( self.manager.submitTask(_tasks.NovaImageList()) ) for image in image_list: # The cloud might return DELETED for invalid images. # While that's cute and all, that's an implementation detail. if not filter_deleted: images.append(image) elif image.status != 'DELETED': images.append(image) return images def get_image(self, name_or_id, filters=None): return self._get_entity(self.search_images, name_or_id, filters)
deleted_lines: for image_id, image in iter(images.items()): def _get_images_from_cloud(self, filter_deleted): # First, try to actually get images from glance, it's more efficient images = dict() try: # If the cloud does not expose the glance API publically image_list = self.manager.submitTask(_tasks.GlanceImageList()) except (OpenStackCloudException, glanceclient.exc.HTTPInternalServerError): # We didn't have glance, let's try nova # If this doesn't work - we just let the exception propagate image_list = self.manager.submitTask(_tasks.NovaImageList()) for image in image_list: # The cloud might return DELETED for invalid images. # While that's cute and all, that's an implementation detail. if not filter_deleted: images[image.id] = image elif image.status != 'DELETED': images[image.id] = image return images @_cache_on_arguments(should_cache_fn=_no_pending_images) def list_images(self, filter_deleted=True): """Get available glance images. :param filter_deleted: Control whether deleted images are returned. :returns: A dictionary of glance images indexed by image UUID. """ return self._get_images_from_cloud(filter_deleted) def get_image(self, name_or_id, exclude=None): for (image_id, image) in self.list_images().items(): if image_id == name_or_id: return image if (image is not None and name_or_id == image.name and ( not exclude or exclude not in image.name)): return image return None

commit_message:
Update server API for get/list/search interface

Support the new search interface, and transform the server objects
to Bunch objects.

Change-Id: Ic8ea3e79863e11b4a00f104557966c81e2f06388

commit_message:
Removing SymmetricKey docs from key module

This change removes the SymmetricKey class references from the key
module doc string. The SymmetricKey class resides in it's own module
and the key module only contains the Key class.

Change-Id: Ic93971584b6bdee5db0042ce8473225f2589a856
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/castellan refs/changes/43/178843/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Base Key Class This module defines the Key class. The Key class is the base class to represent all encryption keys. The basis for this class was copied
deleted_lines: Base Key and SymmetricKey Classes This module defines the Key and SymmetricKey classes. The Key class is the base class to represent all encryption keys. The basis for this class was copied

commit_message:
Drop use of 'oslo' namespace package

The Oslo libraries have moved all of their code out of the 'oslo'
namespace package into per-library packages. The namespace package was
retained during kilo for backwards compatibility, but will be removed by
the liberty-2 milestone. This change removes the use of the namespace
package, replacing it with the new package names.

The patches in the libraries will be put on hold until application
patches have landed, or L2, whichever comes first. At that point, new
versions of the libraries without namespace packages will be released as
a major version update.

Please merge this patch, or an equivalent, before L2 to avoid problems
with those library releases.

Blueprint: remove-namespace-packages
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo-incubator/+spec/remove-namespace-packages

Change-Id: I52848a1f63cb4a1b30d9e1c32f4bb18c5d9fe80e

Drop use of 'oslo' namespace package

The Oslo libraries have moved all of their code out of the 'oslo'
namespace package into per-library packages. The namespace package was
retained during kilo for backwards compatibility, but will be removed by
the liberty-2 milestone. This change removes the use of the namespace
package, replacing it with the new package names.

The patches in the libraries will be put on hold until application
patches have landed, or L2, whichever comes first. At that point, new
versions of the libraries without namespace packages will be released as
a major version update.

Please merge this patch, or an equivalent, before L2 to avoid problems
with those library releases.

Blueprint: remove-namespace-packages
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo-incubator/+spec/remove-namespace-packages

commit_message:
Adds tempest re-install to API/CLI

Uninstall existing Tempest local repo and install from new source and with new
Tempest config file. If source/conf aren't supplied, retrieve from old env
instead of using default source. Copy old conf to temp location and after
installation copy back to verifier.

Implements: blueprint improve-tempest-manage-cli
Change-Id: I410dcc9b5df58213085f727dee3d7fefa0b72b81

added_lines: @mock.patch("rally.api.objects.Deployment.get") @mock.patch("rally.api.tempest.Tempest") def test_reinstall_tempest(self, mock_tempest, mock_d_get): mock_tempest.return_value = self.tempest fake_source = "fake__source" api.Verification.reinstall_tempest(self.deployment_uuid, fake_source) self.tempest.uninstall.assert_called_once_with() self.tempest.install.assert_called_once_with()

subject: Make managing hosts entries optional
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-24 12:11:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/ad48b0c003734f458f84e1534d5dfaf2474111dc', 'message': "Do not manage host entries by default

Diskimage-builder currently writes cloud-init config file which adds a
host entry mapping the hostname and FQDN to 127.0.0.1 into every image
built. This is probably useful for some use cases but not for all, so
images which want this done should do it in their own image elements, it
shouldn't be a part of diskimage-builder's `base` element.

Particular description of the problem this causes in TripleO follows:

We get hosts files like this:

commit_message:
Make managing hosts entries optional

Diskimage-builder currently writes cloud-init config file which adds a
host entry mapping the hostname and FQDN to 127.0.0.1 into every image
built. This is probably useful for some use cases but not for all, so we
now allow customizing the manage_etc_hosts value via
DIB_CLOUD_INIT_ETC_HOSTS variable and also not writing the config at all
if that variable is explicitly set to an empty string (currently the
default is 'localhost' but in the future the default will be empty
string).

Particular description of the problem this causes in TripleO follows:

We get hosts files like this:

    ::1     localhost       localhost.localdomain   localhost6      localhost6.localdomain6
    127.0.0.1       localhost       localhost.localdomain   localhost4      localhost4.localdomain4
    127.0.0.1       ov-rl5i5saoc6h-1-hj5tzsbrdv4c-controller-dy6nuyarqy5z.novalocal ov-rl5i5saoc6h-1-hj5tzsbrdv4c-controller-dy6nuyarqy5z

    # HEAT_HOSTS_START - Do not edit manually within this section!

    192.0.2.17 ov-rl5i5saoc6h-0-wfzcsrqo34p6-controller-m3hy26lhxavl ov-rl5i5saoc6h-0-wfzcsrqo34p6-controller-m3hy26lhxavl.novalocal
    192.0.2.15 ov-rl5i5saoc6h-1-hj5tzsbrdv4c-controller-dy6nuyarqy5z ov-rl5i5saoc6h-1-hj5tzsbrdv4c-controller-dy6nuyarqy5z.novalocal
    192.0.2.16 ov-rl5i5saoc6h-2-a6v7saxnivm5-controller-7jboskte34r7 ov-rl5i5saoc6h-2-a6v7saxnivm5-controller-7jboskte34r7.novalocal
    # HEAT_HOSTS_END

The duplicate hostname/FQDN entry for 127.0.0.1 and 192.0.2.15 confuses
Corosync, which then fails to start a cluster when using hostnames in
the config file instead of IPs.

Change-Id: Ia8582883f737548e2911d3f36a1943e5b236281b
Partial-Bug: #1447497

commit_message:
Don't use scoping information for admin auth

The only place that admin_auth seems to be used here is gaining the
user_id for establishing a trust. Fetching a token for only the user_id
is not an operation that requires scoping to a project so request an
unscoped token here.

Change-Id: Id7c30ec2340addb30d5bd463891c9fdd9280009e

commit_message:
Add missing part for `token` object

Provide some attributes for token which can also be used
in policy language.

Change-Id: Ib09a1765e43502ca9c5d00641b85ab70988bc564
Closes-Bug: #1448991
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/47/182147/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Every target object unless token has an `id` and a `name` available as `target.<object>.id` and `target.<object>.name`. Other attributes are retrieved from the database and vary between object types. Moreover, some database fields are filtered out (e.g. user passwords).* token * target.token.user_id * target.user.domain.id
deleted_lines: Every target object has an `id` and a `name` available as `target.<object>.id` and `target.<object>.name`. Other attributes are retrieved from the database and vary between object types. Moreover, some database fields are filtered out (e.g. user passwords).

added_lines: def build_mcresult(stdout="", sender="1", exit_code=0) rs = {:sender => sender, :data => {:stdout => stdout, :exit_code => exit_code}} it 'should ignore nodes with unconfigured or failed ceph' do mclient.expects(:execute).with({:cmd => osd_cmd}).twice .returns(build_mcresult(stdout="","2", 42)) .then.returns(build_mcresult(stdout=json_resp,"3", 1)) mclient.expects(:execute).with({:cmd => pg_cmd}).never all_nodes = nodes + [{ "id" => "3", "roles" => ["compute", "ceph-osd"], "slave_name" => "node-3"} ] expect(Astute::PreDelete.check_ceph_osds(ctx, all_nodes)).to eq(success_result) end it 'should find live ceph installation' do mclient.expects(:execute).with({:cmd => osd_cmd}).twice .returns(build_mcresult(stdout="","2", 42)) .then.returns(build_mcresult(stdout=json_resp,"3", 0)) mclient.expects(:execute).with({:cmd => pg_cmd}) .returns(build_mcresult(stdout="1\n2")) all_nodes = nodes + [{ "id" => "3", "roles" => ["compute", "ceph-osd"], "slave_name" => "node-3"} ] expect(Astute::PreDelete.check_ceph_osds(ctx, all_nodes)).to eq(error_result) end

commit_message:
Two api tests for 'firewall insertion mode' feature

Some time ago the feature called 'fwaas insertion mode' was merged.
It allows to associate a firewall with routers.

The patchset adds two api tests:
* Create firewall assiciated with a router, add another router
to the firewall, remove old one
* Create firewall assoicited with a router, try to create new
firewall on the same router

Change-Id: I7c4d41189056ff6da47bc1173d3479183e58a173

added_lines: firewall_policy_id=self.fw_policy['id'], router_ids=[router['id']])

commit_message:
Use "regionOne" case in metadata agent conf

Set auth_region to "regionOne" instead of "RegionOne" as the provided
metadata agent default configuration in order to be consistent with docs
and avoid confusion for users.
Also, make it clear this is about the *Keystone* API.

Change-Id: I8f47be1b4b43defb86b4da2a34c5f40494361045
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/22/169222/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: auth_region = regionOne

commit_message:
Add ability to inject routes in interfaces.template

This change adds the ability to inject routes in interfaces.template
by injecting them in the template engine.

It adds support for injecting extra routes when instances are spawned
on networks that do not have DHCP or Neutron routers.

Routes are now found in each interface in the interfaces variable.

The following attributes are available for each route:
  * gateway (eg. 192.168.0.1)
  * cidr (eg. 192.168.10.0/24)
  * network (eg. 192.168.10.0)
  * netmask (eg. 255.255.255.0)

Example of how to inject routes in interfaces.template:

    {% for ifc in interfaces %}
    auto {{ ifc.name }}
    iface {{ ifc.name }} inet static
    # [...]
    {% for route in ifc.routes %}
        post-up ip route add {{ route.cidr }} via {{ route.gateway }} dev {{ ifc.name }}
        pre-down ip route del {{ route.cidr }} via {{ route.gateway }} dev {{ ifc.name }}
    {% endfor %}
    {% endfor %}

Note: Routes are not injected by default in interfaces.template.
This is to avoid any potential conflicts with existing network agents
such as dhcp, l3, etc.

See nova/tests/network/interfaces-override.template for a complete
example on how to interact with the new interface 'routes' attribute.

Blueprint: network-template-routes-injection
DocImpact: Routes are now available in the network template engine.
Change-Id: Ic22c8af721d539c8180b5caa7ba348e834ddbb56
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/09/115409/13 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Add quota check for domain create

added_lines: def quota_get(request, project_id=None): if not project_id: project_id = request.user.project_id d_client = designateclient(request) return d_client.quotas.get(project_id)

commit_message:
Do not update nodes info on not ready nodes

If nodes are not ready or selected for deployemnt post_deployemnt
task for uploading nodes info and updating hosts should not be
executed on them.

Also fixed PEP8 warnings in files I've touched.

Change-Id: Icf2c51ec15f4028ff4da74a633481ca154e42d0a
Closes-Bug: #1450051

commit_message:
Fix InstanceList attribute of instance group to return List

Currently get_attr returns a string of all the ip addresses of the
instance group.This will change it to return a list of ip addresses.

Change-Id: Ic48d4d74ef7feb75a514f850f98f1544a3c06db3
closes-bug: #1454137

Denominator Agent

A new agent backend that uses denominator tool https://github.com/Netflix/denominator
to orchestrate resources of some DNSaaS providers (Dyn, Amazon, Rackspace etc.)

commit_message:
configure-vm: allow multiple baremetal-interface's

This patch updates the --baremetal-interface option such that
multiple values can be passed in using nargs.

Change-Id: If3824e73a68a897c8080aacd65849614fb54b0cc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/76/177876/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: parser.add_argument('--baremetal-interface', nargs='+', default=['brbm'], # FIXME: this only gets us 3 slots until we hit slot 7 (memballoon) slot = 3 params['bm_network'] = "" for bm_interface in args.baremetal_interface: slot += 1 bm_interface_params = { 'bminterface': bm_interface, 'bmmacaddress': generate_bm_mac_address(), 'nicdriver': args.libvirt_nic_driver, 'slot': slot, } params['bm_network'] += """ <!-- bridged 'bare metal' network on %(bminterface)s --> <interface type='network'> <mac address='%(bmmacaddress)s'/> <source network='%(bminterface)s'/> <model type='%(nicdriver)s'/> <address type='pci' domain='0x0000' bus='0x00' slot='0x0%(slot)i' function='0x0'/> </interface>""" % bm_interface_params
deleted_lines: parser.add_argument('--baremetal-interface', default='brbm', 'bmbridge': args.baremetal_interface, 'bminterface': args.baremetal_interface, 'bmmacaddress': generate_bm_mac_address(), params['bm_network'] = """ <!-- bridged 'bare metal' network --> <interface type='network'> <mac address='%(bmmacaddress)s'/> <source network='%(bminterface)s'/> <model type='%(nicdriver)s'/> <address type='pci' domain='0x0000' bus='0x00' slot='0x04' function='0x0'/> </interface>""" % nicparams

commit_message:
force the udp checksum for dhcp

The default vm setting assume udp checksums will be computed in
hardware. This fix forces the appliance to calculate the checksum for
DHCP replies.

This fix was inspired by the upstream reference implementation [1].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/148718/8/neutron/agent/linux/dhcp.py

Change-Id: Id5d4ecdb3ce803b4b2a571f9033a637b7818ee08

commit_message:
Allow libvirt to assign PCI slots for us

This patch updates scripts/configure-vm and the associated
vm.xml template so that we no longer manually assign PCI
slots. Libvirt will assign them automatically for us
and also do things like make sure memballoon is the last
slot as well.

This will help facilitate adding multiple network interfaces
without creating logic to handle the PCI slot assignments.

Change-Id: Ifa8e897ddde52a88e3b25ad267a196d3d9008bc3

commit_message:
Detach from non-func thread

Need to distinguish non-func and usb results in Testrail reports,
so removing thread_non_func_1_usb and create thread_non_func_1
and thread_usb threads

commit_message:
Backup driver for GlusterFS storage

An implementation of Cinder backup driver using GlusterFS as a
backend for Cinder backups.

Implements: blueprint glusterfs-as-a-backup-driver
Change-Id: I79464342f471d39f00c16c04aa29def269c5f28b
